values:
It was nice to get out on my own, just to have a quiet meal and distract myself. I encountered a most interesting woman, who caught my eye quickly. She is differant, but in a good way. Worldly, too. I'm sure I recognised her scent from somewhere.

She called herself Huruma. She was born in Kenya, which is fascinating in itself. The panther seemed rather bitter concerning the ideals of being 'Proper'. Possibly with good reason. She disliked people staring. Shame on me, for she had caught me looking her way as well. I would like to think that my eyes hold no judgement - only curiousity.

I do hope I see her again.

I doubt I have ever been so sickened. So horrible. Not since 

I believe I played the part well. I met Kent himself, as he was supervising the setting up of a... display.

It simply had to be lions...

One could expect a hunting lodge to have trophies from hunts all around, but I was not as prepared as I had thought. Kent has a taste for hunting felines. One day, the felines should hunt him. I would gladly be the one to deliver justice. To dine with such a man, surrounded by the showcased corpses of my kind, was one of the hardest things I have ever done.

I lived a sheltered life. Now I suffer for it. I am weak.

I must contact Desmond and Wes, pass on what I have accomplished. Joseph... I fear for you. I am not religious, but I feel I have to pray for you.

I ate the meat of a shifter. A shifter who was captured, hunted, and cooked. I ate the meat of a person.

I think I might be sick again.



Brother, I used your name. Forgive me.


---

One needs only to look around the lobby of Kent Ranch in order to determine that one of the last things that needs to be added is another piece of taxidermy. All the same, Bartholomew Kent and many of his patrons view such once-living statues as works of art, tributes and testaments to the majesty of the creature that helped to create them as well as to the hunters who helped to bring them into being. The dwarf is dressed in his usual pinstriped suit, but lacks his hat, as he is indoors this early evening. He's hard at work directing a group of men who are assembling a new montage that will sit just inside the doors as a welcoming piece. The rocks that serve as it's base are already up, and the workmen are carefully positioning and securing the single lion and trio of lionesses that will be posed on them as if they were snatched from the African savanna. Barty occasionally shakes back a sleeve in order to check his watch. He really wanted this business done with before dinner.

 

Simple curiosity has brought Ethan Hart to the Kent Ranch today - he's never actually been in the establishment, and for the last few hours the assassin has been quietly wandering the various halls and rooms that he's come across.  The gentle clicking tap of the man's customary ebony cane announces his presence (though this is done only for purposes of being polite) as the small man makes his way back down the stairs to the lobby.  He halts near the bottom step and settles both his hands over the silver deer-head that tips the cane, watching the scene before him.  In some ways, it's amusing.  In others, it's pathetic.

 

Kent Ranch may be a place of leisure for many, but Darius has come this way only because he must. Only just arriving, the shifter has so far been successful in hiding his identity and disgust. His face is clean-shaven, and his black hair is cut short. He wears a black suit, and white gloves on his hands. A modest but effective amount of cologne disguises his scent. All of this work may not really be necessary, but he must be careful. The sight greeting him in the front lobby might make the Frenchman sick if he had any less control. Lions. It /had/ to be lions. Not to mention the array of other unfortunate creatures 'decorating' the Ranch. Taking a silent, deep breath, Darius walks along, past the display and the supervising dwarf. Anything and everything else is ignored, as his golden eyes stare at the display being set up and he must make an effort to not show his horror. /Savages/.

 

Is there really that much difference? Truebloods simply find more uses for the animals they kill, like many ancient cultures. The only difference in the eating habits of most shifters and the guest at the ranch is that the shifters that are eaten here are cooked - and cooked well. Savagery is relative. Bartholomew hasn't seen Darius, nor Hart, before. Or, at least, he can't remember either of them. "Good evening, sir," Bartholomew says to Darius, as the taller man is closer to him than Hart. "I hope it finds you well?" Despite his 'savagery' and exhaustion in having to deal with the workmen, Bartholomew's diction and demeanor is fitting of any well-bred aristocrat. It would take a very keen eye (or a very knowledgeable mind) to catch that he wasn't born into this.

 

The man on the steps simply continues to watch, his eyes flashing oddly red for several moments as he sweeps his gaze around the entire lobby.  The infrared spectrum is infinitely useful, since there are very few individuals that can conceal their presence from it.  It's more of a mild reflex on Hart's part than any actual thought that trouble might arrive, and the fact that he doesn't move from his current perch would indicate that to anyone who knows him... not that anyone here does.  As always, Hart is silently observant.

 

It is a predator's first instinct to kill for food. Displaying the remains as a trophy, however, is even worse than fur. But, Darius supposes it might be good that the rest of the poor creatures are being put to use... even if it is a cruel slap in the face to him and his kind. As he is spoken to, the aristocrat looks down to Barty with a polite smile. "Good evening to you, as well." he returns with a nod of his head. His accent is lighter than normal, perhaps a subconscious effort on his part. He fears the many things that could give him away. "Quite the display you are putting together." He adds in casual compliment, glancing to the lions being set up. How the mighty have fallen. Hart is still unnoticed, although he is aware of the presence of the other man.

 

Of all the things that please the dwarf, stroking his ego is one of the tried-and-true. Bartholomew smiles a bit wider and looks back to the lions. The male is up now, set higher than the females who are all lounging about on the rocks beneath him. "Beautiful, aren't they? It took five years to gather them all." Meaning, purchasing them and bringing them to the Ranch in order to kill them. Big cats aren't cheap.

 

"Weapons," Hart calls out mildly, "are far more interesting to collect and more lasting in their nature.  You can also do far more with an old blade than you can with an old corpse."  The man resumes his walk, starting to step neatly down the remaining steps so he can hit the lobby's floor with the soles of his impeccably polished loafers.

 

"Yes," Darius agrees, voice soft. "They must have been... fantastic creatures in the prime of their lives." He watches the figure of the once-majestic male feline, internally saddened by the fact that the creature will forever be there, dead and immobile. He will never share the beauty of his roar again. The comment from the approaching stranger catches the attention of the shifter, and he tears his gaze away from the morbid scene to look at Hart. Darius can agree with those words, as his own weapon, left at home just in case, is a trophy along with a form of protection. "Weapons and these such trophies," he gestures towards the lions with a gloved hand. "Are both symbols of power to some people. It depends on how you wish to show your own." This is said with a small smile. "To some, the proof of triumph over nature's most dangerous beasts offers more satisfaction than carting around an old blade." Oh, how he despises his own words.

 

Bartholomew , on the other hand, only laughs softly in response to Hart. After Darius has offered his interpretation, the dwarf hums, stroking his chin with one disproportioned hand. "Gentlemen, gentlemen," he says with a shake of his head. "Art is art. Both these," and he waves first to the lions and then around the lobby in general, "and any archaic weaponry one might posses serve but one purpose - to delight the viewer. Old firearms fail, ancient blades grow rusty and brittle with age. They aren't *practical*, by any means. But they *are* enjoyed. That's all they *need* do."

 

As he grows closer, the vague temptation to prove Bartholomew Kent wrong starts to dance itself around Hart's mind.  "I beg to differ."  A swift movement of the man's left forearm loosens a catch on a harness underneath the man's suit, and with practiced ease a small, three-bladed katar has slipped comfortably into the assassin's hand.  He lifts his arm a little, smiling as his fist curls on the grip under the handguard.  "If properly cared for, weapons will never become useless."  The white-haired man stops a ways off from Bartholomew and Darius, suddenly preoccupied with looking over the weapon in hand.

 

A chuckle escapes Darius as he listens to Bartholomew. He then remains silent however, secretly taking a moment to collect himself. His mind is already reeling. This is more difficult than he had expected it to be. The presentation of the bladed weapon causes him to raise his eyebrows a little in interest. Bladed weapons are really a wonder for Darius, but he must keep his interests to himself. He is /not/ Darius when here. "I suppose everyone has their own passions. And artistic views." he comments quietly before casting a glance to Bartholomew. How would he take to this sudden display of weaponry?

 

Bartholomew is, at his core, a weapon's dealer. He lifts his chin to look at the blade along with Hart, nodding his approval after a few moments. Despite their employer's lack of alarm, the various security personnel around the lobby visibly tense as they watch Hart. Who is this man? Weapons themselves aren't uncommon at the ranch, but most carry pistols, rifles, or some other variety of firearm. "That's quite a piece," Bartholomew says with a smirk. He reaches into his jacket to pull the pearl handled revolver from his shoulder holster, holding it so the soft light makes the silver gleam. "You have a point, sir. But it's still aesthetically pleasing, and therefore, still art."

 

Hart slides the fingertips of his right hands along the very edges of the opened primary blade, sliding both halves shut once again over the central one.  "It is not aesthetically pleasing to have mounts when they become indulgently garish and excessive in amount."  His fist uncurls and with another customary gesture, the blade all but vanishes from sight, slipped back up into its hidden sheath.  The only way Hart would fail to notice movement around him would probably require him to be comatose or dead, and since he is currently neither he turns his head to shoot a brief, thin smile at a few of the nearer Ranch guards.

 

This is only a reminder that the place Darius is in is a dangerous one. A bullet from that revolver could be in his chest if he is not careful. He begins to feel a little anxious when the weapons are shown, and the feeling of many eyes pointed in their direction raises the fine hairs on the back of the shifter's neck. Felines are the ones who usually lurk and watch, a reverse situation is not very comfortable. Remaining true to his duty, he covers these feelings. "A shame I left my own firearm at home, I leap at any chance to show it off." He admits with a slightly amused tone, taking his eyes from the revolver to look at Bartholomew. "That reminds me," his head then tilts a little. "Is there someone I could speak to about something along the lines of business? Or is it too late in the evening for that?" The sooner he gets this over with, the sooner he can leave this dreadful place. For now.

 

"What sort of businessman would I be if I denied the donations of customers to the decor of their beloved vacation spot?" Despite Hart's scathing comment, Bartholomew smiles. Not everyone enjoys the various heads on the walls, but that doesn't matter much to him. But 'donate' is the wrong word. It's a little known fact that Bartholomew reduces the cost of a hunt if the carcass is given to the cooks and the skin to the taxidermist in Barty's pocket. Besides, to the dwarf, this 'art' doubles as advertisement. Advertisement that has apparently worked. Barty's smile grows a bit when he looks up to Darius again. Why did he have to be so tall? Hart was much easier to talk to. "You may speak with me, sir." Holstering his revolver, Bartholomew holds out a hand to Darius. "Bartholomew Kent, at your service. Is this something you'd care to discuss in my office, or can I ask you to join me at dinner?" Glancing between the two men, he adds, "The hippopatamus was brought in by Mister Whiting," a prevalent silver merchant. "I'm told that the roast is even better than the usual sausage."

 

If he could pegged as any one thing, Hart would be known as a health nut - and hippopotamus doesn't fit into his diet.  Without another word, the click of the cane is ringing out on the floor once again and the assassin is making his way towards the doors.  There's no need to give his own name, and he knows perfectly well who Kent is.  The other man has appeared to be, at least for now, inconsequential.  It's time for Hart to make his exit.

 

A glance is offered to the departing mutant, and Darius can at least relax a little. No more obsticles in the way, at least. he can focus on speaking to Kent himself. He looks back to Bartholomew and shakes the offered hand, bending down to do so in as subtle of a way as possible. The disguised shifter smiles. "Antoine Baudin. It is a pleasure to meet you." he says in his most polite, respectful tone. "I would love to join you for dinner, if that is not too much trouble."

 

The guards that stand sentry around the lobby and near the door are more than happy to see Hart leave, while Barty himself is a bit disappointed. Still, it wasn't too incredibly odd for someone not fond of hunting to come to the Ranch simply to see what all the fuss was about. With Hart gone, the guards relax a bit. "No trouble at all," the dwarf assures the relative giant. "In fact, I'd be delighted to have your company.  If you go into the restaurant and inform Gaston that you will be dining with me, he will show you to the proper table. I, unfortunately, cannot join you until these men have finished here."

 

The tall man nods and straightens up. "Thank you very much. Take as much time as you need." One more look, a secretly solemn one, is given to the deceased felines before Darius walks off, heading towards the restaurant. He needs no direction, the scents alone can guide him if sight alone cannot help. He gets himself seated with no trouble, and takes this time to take a deep breath. So far, so good. yet, he feels like he could be sick at any given moment. That hippopotamus had to have been a shifter. Just like those lions. Just like him. Seated at Bartholomew's table, Darius can get a good glimpse of the restaurant. For a proud shifter, this is not exactly a prime location to dine in. It is not unlike something from one of the old horror films. The lion in the middle of the room really churns his stomach. Needless to say, he lived a bit of a sheltered childhood. Despite this, the shifter remains calm, and manages to appear more curious than anything as he waits for Kent himself.

 

Before Kent comes to dinner, he takes the time to change into a more fitting suit. After all, dinner is a semi-formal affair, and his usual pinstripes just won't cut it. No, Bartholomew arrives in a sleek black dinner jacket and pants, white shirt, and dark red cravat with a black opal pin. Barty approaches his table with a smile, climbing into his chair with the help of his cane. No sooner has the dwarf seated himself than a waiter brings around a glass of wine for him, pausing to take Darius's order. "I apologize again for the delay, Mister Baudin." Barty says as he adjusts the position of his glass on the table.

 

Perhaps some wine would calm the lion's nerves. He simply asks for some red wine for now, whatever is open and cold at the moment. Then, Darius turns his attention to Kent. "Please, call me Antione." he says with a smile of his own. "And don't worry, I was the one to interrupt, after all." Again, his eyes are drawn to the magnificent lion display in the middle of the room, but he manages to make it appear to be a casual, yet envious glance. "You sure have quite the collection." he comments before finally tearing his eyes away from it. "I plan on starting one of my own. Hence why I am here."

 

Bartholomew can't help but chuckle at the other man's praise of the taxidermy, but then the dwarf nods. Yes, yes. Business. "Well, you can see my own tastes are for felines. Do you have a preference when it comes to prey, or are your tastes more eclectic?" Barty bows his head a bit, extending his hands to either side. "It is my position to cater."

 

"Yes, felines are quite beautiful." Darius says with a faint smirk, now focusing his attention completely on Bartholomew. "I was actually wondering if you allowed hunters to bring in their own to-be trophies? I recently purchased a shifter from the Slaver's Guild, a beautiful serval. Rather than simply have him destroyed, a good friend suggested I come to you. I have done some hunting in my youth, and rather enjoyed it. I see little joy in having this cat displayed in my home with no story or thrill behind it." It frightens him how easily he can slip into a predatory mood, after just feeling so sick.

 

"It's unorthodox," Bartholomew admits with a short hum and a small frown. No, he'd rather people purchase from his own stock. "But I can arrange the field for you, if that's all you desire. However, to ensure your safety, you'd need to bring the serval in in advance so that we can prepare him for you and ensure you have the hunt you desire." Lifting his eyebrows, Bartholomew takes a sip of his own wine. A few moments later, the appetizer is brought, along with Darius's wine. Both men receive a bowl of the wild boar bisque.

 

Although he holds a smile, Darius internally curses. Wes is not going to like that idea one bit. He will talk to Desmond about this, to try and plan the timing to make this as easy as possible. "I am willing to pay any extra fees for this, of course. And I have no doubts I will return for another hunt not too long after, and will see what you have to offer." He holds his demeanour of being a confident man, seemingly unhesitant about his intentions. Yes, it may be strange to bring his own shifter, but he seems to know what he wants. A soft 'thank you' is offered to the waiter, and a sip is taken from his wine -- calmly, but swiftly. After this, another bottle at home may be doomed for consumption tonight. The appetizer smells so good, but at the same time he is secretly reluctant. Was this once a shifter, too?

 

Of course it was! Bartholomew wastes no time in tucking into the soup, but of course, he does so politely. "Actually, if big game interests you, I have a rhino scheduled for the field relatively soon." The dwarf smiles, sitting back a bit as he looks across the table to his guest. "It is, as are your own plans, unorthodox. He's such a rare find, I'm opening him up to several hunters. It will be a competition of sorts to see who can bring down the beast. Of course, there will be spectators as well, if that is more to your liking. It's sure to be a grand event." And it is obvious that Barty is quite proud of it.

 

How sickening that is. If it is not back enough that the poor creature is doomed, a spectacle is to be made out of it. Darius lets the lion think for him and begins eating the soup, knowing he has to play the part. Basic instincts can come in handy. Hungry lion wants meat -- hungry lion has soup. He will cringe and hate himself later. "That sounds like an interesting event." he says, retaining his good manners as he eats. "At the very least, I would love to watch this." The Frenchman nods, seeming very pleased.

 

Bartholomew is also pleased, but his is more genuine. For good reason. "The receptionist will have more information for you." The date, tickets - minor details not fitting for a dinner conversation. "Tell me a bit about yourself, Antione?" Barty raises his eyebrows with interest as he spoons a sip of soup. It's gooood soup.

 

It is only good soup for those who do not wonder about the person they are eating! But Darius stomachs it, purely because he has to. If they serve lion /anything/, he might try to drown himself in his wine. "Thank you, I will definitely look into it." The question about himself is a little unexpected, but the slight surprise is very briefly visible. "Myself? I was born and raised in Bleaker, my folks came from France a after they got married." Think fast, Darius. "My father runs a printing business overseas, which I help him with managing in his old age. A lot of letter writing and paper juggling, but it has given us a comfortable lifestyle." He then smiles again. "Not very exciting I'm afraid, I suppose many upper-level folk have a similar background." Another taste of soup is had, followed by a sip of wine. Desmond had better be damn proud of him. "What about yourself?" He then asks curiously, tilting his head a little. Anything to divert the topic from 'Antione'...

 

"I'm a son of Bleaker, just like yourself," Bartholomew says with a growing grin. "My father was a weapon's dealer, and I, like a good only son, went into the family business." The dwarf pauses to take a sip from his spoon, then his glass. "After he died, I branched out into this, and slowly built all that you see." But in reality, Bartholomew made a good deal of money in the alleys of Bleaker's bottom while his father was still alive, and all of his inheritance is sitting in a safe. None of his father's money has touched the 'canned-hunt' business.

 

Listening with seemingly great interest, Darius continues working on finishing his soup. "It really is quite an accomplishment." he says, giving another glance around. "It is amazing what creatures there are in this world." the shifter adds. This is heartfelt, but not in the exact same context. "Some of these trophies must have been very difficult to acquire. How long has this Ranch been running?"

 

With a whistle after nodding to Darius's praise, Bartholomew leans back in his chair and dabs at his mouth with his napkin. "Oh... ten, thirteen years? The time flies by, though. It's seasonal, but when the winter comes, it pulls out the real afficianados who don't care what sort of weather they hunt in. And the hotel and resort," the spa and restaurant in particular, "get more attention. I do my best to book more entertainment in the off season as well."

 

Then maybe it is about time something is done about this place. Thirteen years of canned hunts is thirteen years far too many. "Quite impressive, I cannot believe I did not learn about this wonderful place sooner." The rest of the evening is a struggle, but Darius, of course, stays true to his goal and remains a grateful gentleman. The hunter is thanked many times for his hospitality, as well. A promise is left that his future trophy will be brought in as soon as possible, and that he and Kent will meet again before long. It is only when he reaches home that the lion's nerves finally get the best of him. At last, the walls crumble, the shifter gives in to his horror and is sick to his stomach.

Darius, slightly disguised and using a fake name (Antione), goes to Kent Ranch. He meets Bartholomew himself, and also a strange man who fancies weapons more than animal skins. 'Antione' proposes his idea for his own canned hunt over dinner.

I shall never understand the maternal instinct of females. Perhaps I am doomed to never understand the supposed fierce loyalty one feels to a spouse.

Isabelle wants to bear the child of her late husband, which is her right. If she has the technology and the resources, I do not see why this dream should not be pursued. But she seemed uneasy, even hesitant to tell me this. She feared it would shatter our friendship. What kind of man would I be if i turned my back on a friend for fufilling a promise?

Yet... I myself am unsure. There is no doubt in my mind that I support her in this descision, but at the same time I am afraid. Am I selfish, thinking she might be the one to drift away?

She assured me she would love the child no matter what, but a small part of me fears that a Trueblood is wanted. My kind are beasts in the public eye. Am I a monster to    I trust her, but sometimes I feel she would despise her child if it was a shifter. A feline  

If anything at all, I want the child to be healthy, mutation or none. That is what matters, right?

I wonder if Mother wanted shifters. If Father was just as proud to admit our mutation as he was proud to admit his own.

I want my children to be shifters

Today I visited the Na'Ostiria estate to see Isabelle again. I believe I needed the company of a close friend such as her. These matters of wolves and ranches will not leave my mind. It was a pleasant visit, and it took an interesting turn when she asked to see me shifted. She said it might help her get over her fear. Thankfully I talked her out of wanting to see me halfway through the shift. That stage is more frightening than anything, in my opinion.

She was nervous at first when I showed her the lion, but did miraclously well. Me being able to speak to her was helpful, as well. I was having my mane pet before long. It is so nice to know that she trusts me, few people in my life have when it came to the feline. I am not a beast, and thank the Heavens that Isabelle knows that.

But still, some of my actions and thoughts in the past while have got me worried. The conflict with the wolf, my reaction to the thief, the very occassional predatory delight I have felt in moments of power... these concern me. Thankfully the latter has not dictated my actions.

I went to see my friend in hopes of forgetting my problems for a while. I suppose that despite the wonderful time we had, everything comes back eventually.

It seems that wolf that the Brute and Red Riding Hood are intending to 'deal with' has his own side to the story, but I expected no less. Adil, his name was. A peculiar fellow, but not as twisted as he was described to me. He claims to want peace between the shifters as well. He has an odd way of attempting to achieve that.

Seeing the man seemingly hunted by so many gave me a strange sense of amusement. In a way it worried me to feel that way. Predatory instinct is irritating to cope with at times. However, he seemed to have a decent head on his shoulders, yet I still I take no sides. Canine politics are something I as a feline will never hope to understand. I will have zero involvement, even if the lady in red happens to find her way to my doorstep and I end up aiding her.

Adil said her name was Braun. It is good to get her last name, but I like my little name for her more. I do hope she is doing well.

Still, the familiarity of her scent bothers me. It will not leave my mind.

Well, I suppose I have other things that require my attention. Like Joseph's task in the Ranch plan. I should get in contact with Wes and Desmond soon, as well.

The wolves of Bleaker are strange creatures, but I cannot help but worry for them. Well, the decent ones, at least.

I hate to use such snobbish terms, but that male canine was a brute. No respect at all, not even for women. That sickens me. I also despise the word 'cat' being used that way. One day, hopefully, he will get his. Never have I had to draw my sword out of fear and reflex. Thankfully I did this afternoon, though.

That woman was a strange one, but not necessarily in a bad way. I can tell life has been throwing quite a bit at her. Her shaved head, the wound, the knives, they all captured my curiousity. She was a wolf as well, but much more civil than the male. A stronger soul, as well. I regret acting so violently in front of her.

I gave her my name and the location of my home, whether she comes for help or not is her choice. My home is always open for a shifter in dire need. It is a shame I never got her name. I will, however, probably never forget her. I know that scent from somewhere, I just cannot recall where...

I found the irony of her attire more memorable than her sheared head. A wolf in a red cloak. It makes me think of the old, old story of the little girl and the big bad wolf. I remember the story of Little Red Riding Hood from my childhood. Mother loved reciting it to me, even if it is from so long ago.

I believe that is how I will remember her. Little Red Riding Hood.

With Estelle fed and resting, Ilse has taken to wandering Bridgelight. She's donned her red cloak to stave off the slight chill in the late afternoon air, but she finds she has to hold it shut when she stands on the beach amongst a small scattering of driftwood. The wind that comes off the bay flaps at the tattered edges of the red. Her hood is up, hiding her eyes as she gazes thoughtfully off across the water as blue as they are today.

 

The beach is a nice, quiet place for one to go to think, if the wind can be braved. Shielded against the chilly breeze by a warm, black overcoat, Darius is walking along the sand, keeping a safe distance away from the lapping waves. In his right hand he casually but expertly swings his beloved sword, also twirling it to admire the way the light bounces off of it. The remains of shredded and dismembered driftwood in the sand quite a distance behind him are a hint as to how he spent the beginning of his afternoon. It was not to let out any anger or energy, but just to help clear his mind. Only after a while does he notice the woman in the red cloak ahead, and he slows his pace a little. The wind may be coming off the water, but the lion shifter is fortunate enough to catch a scent off of her. It is oddly familiar, but he cannot recollect knowing the female, who seems to be canine. He continues along, sword still out although the twirling has ceased.

 

The wind off the water doesn't just blow straight, but dances on the flat expanse, swirling around. As it does this, Darius's scent tickles Ilse's nose. Her first thought is that the lion is a member of the Blood Meridian, but she often thinks that when faced with large feline shifters. She turns her head, blue eyes brightening for a moment as she watches Darius slowly draw nearer. No, she doesn't remember his scent from the old headquarters, but that doesn't mean anything. The sword grabs her attention next. "Compensating?" she asks boldly, but in a casual tone when the lion is close enough to hear. Why would a lion need a secondary weapon?

 

The statement does not go unheard, and Darius calmly looks up to her again. Despite the surprise given to him by the wolf's statement, he only smiles politely. "Family heirloom, actually." He does not put the sword away, but might if she begins to appear uneasy. The lion keeps walking, intent on passing by her, although his pace is now much slower. "Although I suppose it might give the impression I lack something." The Frenchman only seems calmly amused by this strange woman. "Much like that cloak may say you have something to hide, non?"

 

The insuination strikes a chord with Ilse, who frowns deeply. She has no reason to hide, and so she releases her grip on the cloak so that it flies out with the next gust of wind, revealing the ratty jeans and the shirt she borrowed from her brother's closet. As the wind whips and dances, the bottom of the shirt lifts to offer the lion a glimpse of the white bandage around her abdomen. Ilse then lifts her hands to lower her hood, revealing her shorn head. "It's cold, is all," she says before she lifts it again to save her ears. She glances to Darius's hands, looking to see if his nails are intact. "You haven't been declawed, kitty. And most people who have heirlooms keep them safely put away." Or wear them, in the case of Varick's coat. But Ilse had long since given it to Imre - who it more rightly belonged to (and who it probably fit better).

 

For once alone, and for once without an arsenal with him, Charon stalks through the alleys of Bridgelight and soon comes out on the waterfront.  Stray scents have lead him this far, and haven't led him wrong; the canine is what you'd call an advanced tracker.  He strolls out towards the two conversationalists at a slow and easy pace, hands tucked into his ill-fitting trousers.  The fingerless gloves, ratty clothing, and patched bowler set the man very much apart, but that doesn't matter.  He seems to have a destination in mind.  That destination is the female.

 

The lion's intention was not to upset the woman to any degree, but he stops to look at her. A small sense of admiration comes to Darius as he sees Ilse and what the cloak previously covered. He does not, however, allow room for sympathy, as she does not strike him as the type to really want any. But at the same time, he wonders, he wishes to ask many questions. The bandaged wound, sheared head, and knives beg for so many inquiries. What has this world done to you? Before he can speak, the next comment averts his attention. The sword, then his nails (which are indeed intact) are given a glance. "Most do, yes. But this heirloom is neither for display or for battle, it is with me at all times. I suppose it may be too sentimental to hang above a mantle forever." Then, a movement catches Darius' eye, and the Frenchman looks over to spot another male. Another wolf. The lion says nothing, only glances to Ilse again.

 

It's when Darius recognizes Charon's approach that Ilse turns her head just enough to get a good look at the Master of Claws. Her jaw tightens, and behind tight lips she grits her teeth. "I suppose that whomever gave it to you must be proud then," she responds, but her tone hints of an absent mind. She pulls her cloak closed again, presumably in an continuation of the battle against the wind.  Her icy eyes, which are brighter than they were when she gazed across the water, are locked on Charon.

 

Charon is smiling.  Charon is /usually/ smiling, but this is Smile Number 412, and it says: 'Hot damn, you're fucked'.  The greyback's smile only gets wider, and he very conveniently chooses to ignore Darius' existence.  In the wolf's mind, the lion isn't worth the time of day any more than a trueblood is, and he'd sooner rip out a trueblood's throat than glance at his watch.  If he had a watch.  Details.  His ambling gait takes him in a direct line, and once he's close enough to be within earshot he lets out a chuckle.  "It's not smart to wander about alone in these parts."

 

Eyes refusing to leave this newcomer, Darius falls into silence. Not an accepting, 'I'll shut up and let you wolves speak' silence, oh no. It is one of those calculating silences, as he attempts to read the other man. He may be a man of patience, but something about Charon just makes the lion cautious. The only sound from him is the slow metallic sound of his sword sliding back into the sheath under his overcoat. He allows Ilse to answer.

 

So Charon *is* in the 'Ilse is a Dumbfuck' club. Good to know. The former greyback tucks her chin as she glares at Charon and that smile. "It's not safe for *you* to be out alone in these parts, you mean.  Claribel and I have an arrangement. Last I heard, she still wanted to pain the Red Light District with your blood." She glances to Darius, noting his posture. Leave it to Charon to ruin a possibly pleasant conversation.

 

"No one gives a fuck about fucking Claribel, except maybe her idiot girlfriend."  Charon continues to ignore Darius, since the feline has made it clear - in Charon's mind - that he's going to defer to his betters.  "And I don't give a fuck about any arrangement you might have.  You," says the greyback, coming in close enough to jab one forefinger into Ilse's chest, "have got yourself a problem, and I have me the same problem.  It's named Adil, and it's stupid as a pile of rocks."

 

Although he feline is ignored, he is still right there, soaking in every word exchanged between the wolves. /Obviously/ this is not a friendly relationship. Darius can only keep his patience until Charon closes in on Ilse and jabs at her. A loud, sudden growl erupts from the lion as he reaches out to roughly set a hand on the other male's chest, and attempts to push him back and away from the woman. "Hands off the lady." he snarls, old habits and anger taking over. In his culture, such a gesture against a woman is unspeakable. Already his fingernails and teeth have grown and sharpened a little. Back off.

 

Even with Darius's intervention, Charon's poke finds it's target. Whether or not it stays long is another story - one the lion is sure to help write. Still, the lion coming to her defense draws a smug sort of smile from her. Look at me, she thinks, a wolf with kitty mionions. But Charon's words are troubling, if only for the memories they bring to the surface of Ilse's clouded mind. "Fucker called me petty," she growls. It's a sore spot, and one Ilse has dwelt on. "Ordering me around like I'm still part of my ol - *his* pack." She pauses, eyes narrowing a bit futher before she tilts her head to one side. "Did you know he whips himself? Are *all* your Claws that twisted?"

 

Most - if not all - of Ilse's response is lost to Charon in a swift wash of rage that makes the man see red.  He's been touched by a cat.  The greyback roars back at Darius, both hands coming up to shove back at the stranger's chest in a way that's far from gentle or friendly.  "Keep to your own fuckin business, cat!  Piss off to whatever litterbox you're haunting."

 

Charon may despise cats, but they have one attribute that is arguably invaluable -- superb balance. As he is shoved, Darius is able to shift his weight and dig his feet into the sand enough to not fall, or even slide very far. Another growl escapes him as one now-clawed hand makes a grab for the wolf's wrist. "/Salaud/!" he hisses in his native tongue, his tone giving anyone a hint that it is a foul insult. Few very things truly anger the usually friendly aristocrat, and two of them are disrespect for a woman, and disrespect of his kind. He says nothing more, as the wolf is entitled to no words at the moment.

 

"BOYS!" Ilse's growl has risen to an all out snarl as she takes a step back. She doesn't speak French, but she can recognize the language both from Darius's use of a negative earlier and the sound of it. "Calm the *fuck* down, will you? Kitty, nothing you say or do will get this cur to respect me *or* you. Save your strength for a battle that matters more and that you can win." Like one against hunters or slavers. But then again, uniting felines and canines (and all shifters) against their oppressors has been Ilse's dream for years.

 

The greyback's hand twists once Darius grabs it, and soon the thing is bristling with fur as Charon begins to make a shift to crinos.  Right in public, too, though this particular area is rather out-of-the-way.  Calming down is not currently on the to-do list, and within seconds a set of fine jaws with cruel teeth are lunging forward to snap at Darius' face.  No one ever accused the Claw leader of being polite.  The cat /touched/ him.  /Again/.

 

Well, Darius was willing to be the bigger man and end this confrontation, but soon he finds himself in more danger than expected. He lets go of the wolf's hand and steps back quickly. A flicker of surprise can be seen in his expression, although it is fleeting. The sword is drawn with lightning speed. He is not shifting so quickly, but fur and more feline characteristics are beginning to show. There is no room to hold the blade out straight, but Darius makes an upward slash, hoping to get the other shifter's belly or chest. Whether that hits or not, the lion is already beginning to leap out of the way.

 

Ilse sinks back and drops to sit on a piece of driftwood with a groan that is a mix of pain and frustration. "Hurry up an have your damned pissing match so we can go back to civilized conversation, please?"

 

Faces aren't made out of metal, and Charon has been blessed with a set of above-average reflexes.  As soon as the sword is seen he balks and stops, leaving himself safely short of the slash as Darius jumps away.  The wolf's fur ridges up all around his body and he simply growls, peeling his lips back from his teeth enough so that his gums can be seen.

 

Catching his footing and straightening up, Darius remains in the same form, as shifting any further may tear his clothing. He is a /big/ cat, after all. The sword is now pointed straight out, towards the hostile wolf. "No more." he snarls, knowing that the lady is right. His teeth only show for another moment before he begins to shift back into human form. He remains defensive, only because he fears this canine will jump at him again. "Let us listen to the woman. I am not here to feed your petty hatred for my kind." They are all shifters, should that not be enough? The feline takes a small step back, signifying he wants nothing more to do with the fight.

 

Charon freely chooses to take the lack of violence, coupled with his dominant display, as an act of submission on the part of the feline.  He snorts derisively, and the lupine features start to melt back into his body to leave normal skin.  "The 'woman' isn't any sort of fuckin' lady anyone's ever heard of.  I must've missed you when I was drowning the other kittens."  A flash of a sneer accompanies the wolf's full return to human form, and he then turns his gaze on Ilse.  "Adil's a moron.  Always has been.  I'll get rid of him for you for ten thousand chits."

 

Being called a woman is slightly offensive, but at least the two males aren't at each other's throats anymore. So Ilse has won, sort of. "Why should I pay you to get rid of a problem that is *also* your problem? I could just sit right here," and Ilse pats the driftwood, "and just wait for you to get rid of him yourself, and that won't cost me a damned penny. And I don't think you've ever met a 'lady' in your damned life." Glancing to Darius, Ilse smirks. "Kitty here probably has. But he has something they call 'manners.'"

 

Calmly, although his eyes never move from the wolf, Darius returns his weapon to it's place. Never has he drawn the blade out of reflex in such a manner. Then again, his old life held very little danger and brutes like this one. Well... most of his old life. The name apparently given to him causes the lion to give Ilse a brief glance, but he offers no real reaction to it and returns his gaze to Charon. He remains prepared for another lunge, whether it may be toward himself or the female. As much as this violent canine floods Darius with anger, he remains silent, having faith that Ilse can handle this on her own.

 

Charon sneers.  "Ain't no need for me to evict him from your place if he ain't bothering me or I ain't getting /paid/," he snaps.  "You'd think that'd be clear enough, but I guess that a bitch who can't keep her own pack wouldn't be able to put two and two together on her own anyway."  'Kitty' is, once again, being ignored.  Charon is so polite.

 

"He's already your problem, Charon," Ilse sighs, wishing she could lean back and alleviate pain with sheer posture. "He's talkin' about war. War against *you*. Wanted me to protect some bitch of his in your ranks." Knowing Charon to be a more 'naturalistic' alpha, Ilse smirks subtly. "Which surprised me, to tell you the truth. I didn't know you *let* males in your pack mate with your females." Because they all must clearly belong to Charon. Clearly.

 

Although it is obvious there is something horrible wrong amongst the wolf packs, Darius still finds some canine behaviours strange. Then again, he is a feline, which are much differant. Although no words are spoken, a cold glare and a tense exhale are given when Charon speaks rudely to Ilse. Still he stands, almost like a finely dressed French bodyguard, by Ilse. Up until now, he had no reason to dislike any wolves. Charon seems the type to ruin things for everyone.

 

The male wolf shifter curls his lip and turns, shrugging his shoulders as he goes.  "If you don't want my help, bitch, that's your call.  Have fun dealing with Adil sitting in the middle of your living room."  And then he's back down an alley and out of sight, and the remnants of a hoarse chuckle can be heard for a time after he's gone.

 

"If he can fucking find it!" Ilse yells after Charon, her face wrinkled in a frown. Part of her is tempted to go to Charon's own territory and continue negotiations. After all, if she can get Charon to get Adil in one spot, she can finish the job like she wants. But she doesn't have ten grand. She doesn't even have five.

 

Watching Charon disappear, Darius does not relax until the damned wolf is definitely gone. He then turns to Ilse, steps a little closer and kneels down in the sand. He does, however, keep a respectful distance. "Miss, I know little of the situation at hand," he begins, voice softened in comparison to his previous snarling. "but you seem to be between a rock and a hard place, so to speak. All of this may be none of my business, I know." He sighs. "Can I offer my aid in any way?" A risky offer, yes, but the woman seems to have been through enough. It is his /habit/ to offer help to a fellow shifter.

 

Unlike Charon, Ilse has nothing at all against cats. Hell, she was mated to one for a time. "You can. But that's what he just did, and you saw how I didn't accept it." But really only because she doesn't have the money and doesn't want to be in that particular wolf's debt. "But like you said, you don't know what's going on."

 

Taking a deep breath, the lion nods his head in a solemn manner. "I understand." He then looks up to her again after taking a moment to think. "Despite the shameful display I put on, I am not usually one to encourage violence. However... how badly do you want this Adil fellow gone?" he asks. Darius does not know this woman's name, but he feels that he should know her. He has caught that scent before. Also, seeing her unfortunate state, he feels compelled to aid her. "Or, how much of a threat is he to you and those you care about?"

 

"He doesn't know where they are," Ilse says with a sigh and a shake of her head. "He's a nuisance, but a dangerous one. Crazy, too. But like... a quiet crazy. Whips himself for fun and challenged me for no goddamned reason, except maybe to prove he could." And as far as Ilse's concerned, Adil lost that battle. There's more to leadership than brawn.

 

This description of this strange wolf earns a funny look from Darius, one that is part confusion and part disgust. "Sounds like a man too sick to be taken lightly." he remarks. After a moment, possibly one of hesitation, Darius reaches into the inner chest pocket of his overcoat. A pen and small leatherbound datebook are pulled out (A PADD is too much technology for an old fashioned fellow like himself), and he scribbles something on the back, blank page before ripping it out. He folds it in half and gently presses it into the woman's hand. Written down is his first name, and his address. No last name is given, just in case. "Call me a fool, but I trust you with this information. Do whatever you please with this, just know that if you feel yourself to be in serious danger, my door is open to /any/ shifter in need." He gives Ilse a small smile before standing up and placing the items back into his pocket.

 

The gift of information is a surprise, despite Darius's obvious willingness to help her. Ilse doesn't open the paper, but slips it into her pocket with a smirk. "Why is it that felines are so much easier to convince that we're better off working together than snarling at each other?" Despite all of her fights with Desmond, he wanted to see a united front just as much as she did. Her smirk fades as she slips back into contemplation.

 

While Ilse's smirk fades, his smile remains. "We shifters sometimes fail to acknowledge the advantages of peace within our species. It is a shame, but I still have hope." A glance is offered to the skies, as it seems about time to get going home. "I am afraid I must be on my way, miss. Will you be alright to walk home?" He knows some women may take offense to such an offer, and would not have voiced it if it were not for that strange, violent wolf that had only just departed. He can tell, however, that this female is a strong one. She has endured many hardships, it seems.

 

"I'll be fine, thank you." Ilse won't walk home though. Or, at least, not to her current one. She has more to think about, and if she won't contact her beta to tell him where she is, she certainly won't lead a lion she barely knows to her doorstep. "Goodnight, oh lion-hearted one." The parting sentiment is said with another smile.

I have not been dancing in years, not since I was in my late teens and trying to win over the hearts of all the pretty young women in town. It is good to know I have not forgotten the steps. The waltz is such a beautiful dance, and Lady Na'Ostiria simply amazed me. Apparently she has been dancing since she was a child, and it shows. I believe just going out for an evening was what we both needed. Certain stress has been weighing both of us down lately.

I believe in what I said to her; she really is a gem. In a city where people are too concerned with thier next bout of satisfaction and have thier intentions flooded with ulterior motives, here is a beautiful woman spending her long days trying to help people. In a way, Isabelle humbles me. But at the same time she carries herself with such dignity. This is how I see her, but some part of me remains cautious.

I fear that I may be getting attatched to her. A little too attatched for the potentially dangerous nature of our affilations. I feel guilty for not telling Isabelle the truth, but doing so would only end in hurt feelings and complications. But the Lady certainly has her charms. It is only the ties of her family, and her hate for the Blood Meridian, that give me so much concern.

Oh, how the road of life twists in peculiar ways.

I know not how to tell thee who I am:
My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself,
Because it is an enemy to thee;
Had I it written, I would tear the word.
~Romeo and Juliet - Shakespeare

I am still feeling concerned about the whole Ranch attack plan. Mostly because I now have unsettled thoughts and rumours about the Blood Meridian now floating around my mind. Meeting with Desmond again was helpful, but at the same time some of my fears have yet to be alleviated.

Joseph was nervous of the puma at first, which is understandable. Once assured he will not be there during the raid or left behind, he seemed a lot better. Desmond was quite nice to him, but was not afraid to voice his concerns when we spoke in private. I am nervous for him, but I am entirely confident in Joey's ability to complete this task with the utmost success.

I wanted to ask about Glen Murdoch, the hunter that Isabelle told me about. But I dared not mention something so dark with Joey present. No need to scare the young hedgehog further. Perhaps after this Ranch business is over, I might bring it up.

Well, should I? Desmond is a nice fellow, but he... he reminds me of father. A perfect gentleman, but there is something just beyond that face he shows to the world. I believe it was Robertson Davies who wrote about every person having twenty sides to them. I know it is old fiction before the days of our world, but it holds very true. Desmond seems like a fine example of that. I fear it may start to apply to myself as well.

Being a bachelor now means that Desmond gets to eat out a lot.  Ah, what a joy.  This particular evening, however, he's actually meeting someone.  The puma is tucked into a booth within sight of the front door, dressed in black pinstripes and with a glass of water in front of him.  He hasn't ordered yet, but is perusing the menu.  It would be rude to order before his guests arrived, now wouldn't it?

 

Desmond does not have to wait long, as Darius enters the restaurant a short time after he does, with a young man in tow. The one with him looks a little nervous, but is trying his hardest to wear a confident expression. Spotting Desmond without trouble, the lion smiles and they make their way over to their booth. "Desmond. Good evening." he says warmly, although in the back of his mind there is a dull sense of uneasiness, never forgetting what Isabelle had told him. He places a hand on his friend's shoulder. "This is Joseph, my cook." The boy looks no older than nineteen, and he stands stock still, large green eyes on the puma. He has the scent of a rodent; a hedgehog to be precise.

 

When the others arrive, Desmond glances up from his menu with a warm smile.  "Ah, good evening, Darius, Joseph," he greets, nodding to each in turn.  "Pleasure to meet you."  This, obviously, is directed at the young hedgehog.  The puma indicates the booth with a wave of one hand.  "Please, sit.  I was just getting ready to order."  There are already two menus set out for the other two shifters.

 

 Darius sits first, followed by Joey. The hedgehog lowers his eyes to the menu, perhaps to distract himself, and takes a deep, but silent breath. He has to be calm. He wanted to help, so he has to keep his cool. Darius only directs a small smile towards his friend before looking to the other feline again. "How have you been, Desmond? It has been a while."

 

"It has."  Desmond seems to have finally decided on something and sets aside his menu, then settles back into the bench and folds his hands on the table in front of him, smiling all the while.  "I've been well.  And yourself?"  He would rather the topic of discussion not linger on his own state of being.

 

"No complaints. Things have been well enough." No reason to mention the stress the past day or so has brought him, especially considering it has to do with the puma himself. /Those/ kinds of questions can come later. His eyes lower to look down at his menu for a moment. "How are the plans coming along?" he does not mention which ones, as this is a public place, but he hopes Desmond will catch on to what he means.

 

It doesn't take a genius to understand what Darius is getting at--it only requires an insider's knowledge, which Desmond happens to have.  The puma smirks slightly and bobs his head a little.  "They are coming along well.  Actually, that's why I asked to meet you and your young friend today."  Obviously, they're needed.

 

At that, Joey raises his head and looks at Desmond, but says nothing. By the way he seems so nervous, Darius finds it a wonder that the boy even wanted to help. Perhaps it is the smell of puma that is making him even more uneasy. "I assumed as much." the lion says before his voice lowers a little. Not enough to be suspicious in any way, just to keep his words inside their booth. One can never be too careful. "When exactly will we be needed?"

 

"Tomorrow," Desmond responds with a small lift of his eyebrows, his voice equally confidential.  He glances to Joseph with a faint, almost reassuring smile.  Yes, the smell of rodent is tantalizing on an instinctive level, and moreso since the puma is currently hungry, but in human form, Desmond has great mastery over himself and his instincts.  "If you feel ready enough for it, that is.  You will have to . . . do something about the smell.  I can recommend and even supply a good cologne."

 

Tomorrow seems like short notice, but they can work around that. If he had not been so nervous, Joey might have been offended by the comment about his scent. "I have plenty at home that I have come to use often." Darius replies with a nod. "I can lend some to Joey for the time being." The lion has found himself masking his scent all too often, because who knows what might happen. He dislikes it greatly.

 

Desmond doesn't make such efforts.  He is what he is, and he feels no need to hide it like something of which to be ashamed.  The puma nods slowly.  "See about offering him up as staff, then," he remarks, "and pray that the bait is taken."  It's a big fish he's looking to land, after all.  A waiter slowly begins to approach to take orders, and Desmond falls silent.

 

Covering up his scent is not an act of shame for Darius, as he is quite proud of what he is. However, his life so far in Bleaker has given him ample reason to be a little more subtle. Joey looks to his employer, and gets a warm smile in silent reassurance. Darius is just as nervous; however, knowing this should not be taken lightly. As the waiter arrives, Darius and Joey give their orders, a steak and a vegetarian dish, respectively. Joey's voice is quiet, but his tone and words are very respectful and polite.

 

 A dish of some sort of chicken is ordered for Desmond, given in fluent Italian, and then the waiter collects the menus and leaves.  Once they're alone again, the puma turns his attention to his guests, smiling faintly all the while.  "Have you any other questions?"

 

Darius seems rather impressed by Desmond ordering in another language, and his approving smile shows it. He looks to the puma again, shaking his head before glancing at Joey. The hedgehog fidgets a little with the cloth napkin in front of him. "I-- er, are you guys gonna leave me behind after..." he trails off, beginning to stare at the napkin as if it is the most interesting thing in the room right now. The thought of being left after the raid is one of his biggest fears.

 

But it's an unwarranted fear.  Desmond would never allow an innocent shifter to be left behind in such a fashion, and he shakes his head, smile growing.  "Absolutely not.  You will most likely not even be there for the entire thing.  We simply need you to give us what information you can gather, and we will do the rest."

 

Joey seems rather relieved, and Darius is also reassured by hearing this again. The rodent nods with a small smile, tearing his green eyes from his current distraction to look at Desmond. "Alright. Thanks." He then quietly excuses himself and slips out of the booth, heading towards the washroom. He needs to take a minute to think and let it sink in. Also to calm down so his hands might stop shaking. Darius silently watches the boy disappear around the corner, seemingly concerned.

 

And so is Desmond, but he doesn't let on until the boy is long out of sight and earshot.  Then, he looks to Darius with a lifted eyebrow.  "Are you certain he is up for the job?" he inquires, sounding slightly dubious.  "He seems . . . jittery."  And a jittery person is really not the sort to be doing such tasks.

 

Darius had been afraid of a question like that, but he calmly looks to the puma and nods. "He is a slightly skittish boy, but Joey never lets his nerves get in the way when he is focused on a task. I cannot describe how determined he is to help. It baffles me, seeing how nervous he is around strangers, but I have faith in him." Darius' tone implies he takes this seriously, which he does. This is not something to be taken lightly.

 

"Determination is one thing, and an admirable trait," Desmond intones with a slight nod, "but so is the ability to hold up under pressure."  And God, will there be pressure.  "It isn't his willingness that I question; it's whether or not he will crack and foul up the entire thing, should he be caught."  It isn't something to be taken lightly, and this is precisely why.  One tiny slip and the whole plot is ruined.  Several lives could be lost.

 

"I assure you, Desmond, that he is capable of handling the pressure." Darius replies, unquestionably confident in his words. "His only fear is being left behind, and I think the assurance you gave him is enough. I made sure that Joseph understands how much depends on his success, and he still believes he can do it." It may be hard to convince the other feline, based on Joey's behaviour, but Darius is stubbornly determined that the young chef can pull this off.

 

Desmond considers a moment before he finally nods slowly.  Darius knows the boy more than the Meridian leader, and thus the puma will have to put his trust in the aristocrat.  Which also means the lion will be held accountable should Joseph prove himself less than satisfactory.  "Very well," Desmond states, smiling faintly.  "I will check in next week to see if he has progressed any in terms of useful information."  The waiter arrives again, bearing plates and drinks, and as he serves, Desmond goes silent once again.

 

Darius would not have spoken so confidently if he had a second thought about Joey's competence. He is also more than willing to be held responsible if the boy happens to fail. As the waiter comes by again, Darius also says nothing except to thank him when the meals are set down. At the same time, Joey slips back into the booth, silent like before. He does appear significantly calmer, however.

 

The waiter leaves again, and Desmond smiles at Joey when the boy returns.  "So, Joseph," he utters, beginning to tuck into his steak in the usual fast, efficient fashion, "how long have you been a chef?"  The Kent Ranch's staff is very elite; the puma would like to know if the hedgehog will fit in.

 

Although a little surprised to be spoken to so suddenly, Joey smiles a little. "I've been cooking for twelve years, sir." he replies with a small nod. When it comes to cooking, Joey really shows his confidence. "Since I was seven." Of course, the first few years had only been spent helping in the kitchen, but it was still a huge part of his life back then.

 

Desmond , himself, was a kitchen lad at that age.  Unfortunately, he failed to pick up any culinary talent--which is why his garbage at home is full of takeout boxes.  The puma shows interest at this, and it's clear that he's impressed.  Joey's change in demeanour is noted, however slight, adding credence to his claims.  "Very good," Desmond rumbles.  "You should fit in well, then."

 

The fact that Desmond seems pleased with this helps Joey relax a little, and the boy smiles again. "Thank you, sir." And with that, he begins eating. Darius also seems a bit more at ease, and he beams at his young chef. "How is Wesley doing these days?" the lion then asks Desmond. Considering the two had only met once, Darius quite likes the serval and looks forward to seeing him again soon, even if they then will have to begin working together to help with the Ranch attack.

 

"He's doing well, as far as I know," Desmond responds with a small bobbing of his head.  As is normal, the puma is already halfway through his plate.  Ah, the life of the fast eater.  "I understand he's contacted you?"  This is most pleasing.

 

"That is good to hear." the aristocrat says with another smile. "And yes, we have met already. Quite a nice fellow." Darius adds while nodding. It was good to meet the man before they began thier task at the Ranch. It seemed to help alleviate Wes' fears about being caged up and putting his trust in a complete stranger. Joey is content to listen as he eats, being a quiet sort of man.

 

"Yes, he is."  Desmond smirks.  The rest of dinner is spent with small talk, for the most part, before all three shifters part ways once the plates are empty.  Desmond returns home feeling a little more confident and accomplished as far as his scheme is concerned.

Darius and Joey meet with Desmond.

This is not what I had in mind. I should have been more careful.

I know the Blood Meridian is known for extreme tactics; explosives, kidnappings and the like. Perhaps I overlooked it or underestimated the grave reality of it to ease my own mind. After a morning of running errands, the idea of lunch has become quite tempting for Darius. And the Rovigatti Deli is conveniently placed on the way home. After getting himself a seat, the lion shifter glances around at all he can see from his table. Funny how he had passed this establishment almost every day, and never thought to visit it before. Since he had been out with business in mind, Darius is dressed for it, as always. His overcoat has been left hung up near the table, leaving him in black pants, a white business shirt, and a dark green suit vest. He glances out one of the large windows, noticing the many clouds in the sky and unsure if the afternoon will bring sunshine or rain.

 

A familiar figure passes Darius' window and steps inside, removing her overcoat and talking to the matre de, it is Isabelle Na'Ostiria who upon seeing the lion raises a hand in greeting, "Darius my dear, how have you been?"

 

While gazing outside, Darius does catch sight of his good friend, and is rather thrilled to see she is entering the restaurant. It has been too long since he had shared a chat with Isabelle. Watching her enter, the shifter smiles in return. "I have been well enough, Isabelle. What about yourself?" He then gestures to the seat across the table from him. "Would you care to join me?"

 

Isabelle smiles at the invite and moves to sit down, "I have been...low, so I have come out of the office to get away from it all and seeing your face makes me smile." She orders a drink and then turns to Darius, "How have you and yours been?"

 

Ordering a drink for himself as well, Darius then focuses on the woman again. "Things have been alright, but eventful to say the least." he replies. It has not been the best week or so, but now he is concerned about his friend. "Problems at the clinic?" the lion shifter asks, tilting his head a little. He usually sees her in a cheerful mood and with endless smiles.

 

Isabelle sighs, "Not problems no, just friends of mine being hurt. An old friend of the family Glen Murdoch, was kidnapped and tortured by those terroists the Blood Meridian, he had lung cancer....he he finally sucumbded...it just...is wrong that he had to spend the last weeks of his life lying in a hospital bed."

 

Hearing this might just be the equivalent of being jolted with electricity, but Darius puts effort into not showing it. He does appear stunned, but not to the extent he actually feels. "Tortured?" Is... that what the Blood Meridian really does? He knows Desmond is a bit extreme in his opinions and ideas, and the Ranch attack plan is a good example of that, but torture? "That is very unfortunate." he then says in a solemn manner, lowering his eyes a little. "Did he at least go peacefully after all that?"

 

Isabelle stares at Darius, "Yes they torture and maim! I'm all for stopping hunting but their methods are just wrong. I am convinced they convinced young Ian to attack the Hunting lodge, which saw him dead but of course I have no proof. Zero Tolerance cannot even move in to stop them from more killing because we have no leads." She shakes her head and slumps in her chair, "Sorry...Darius dear, it has just been...very stressful."

 

It is hard for Darius to believe this. It is even more difficult to hide the fact that he is growing a little pale in the face. Is all of this true? He trusts Isabelle, and he also believes that he has to trust Desmond. Looking up again to the Lady, the shifter extends his hand and lays it palm-up on the table, offering it to her in a friendly, comforting manner. "Please, do not apologize. It sounds like you could use to get some of this off your chest, Isabelle." he says to her, tone soft.

 

Isabelle sighs and cradles her drink, staring into the liquid, "Ian died from his wounds, wound that should have killed him there and then, But he was a bull. A bovine attacked the hunting lodge. The day before Glen Murdoch was turned into my care, broken, battered, I saw his wounds, I treated him. He had been tortured then released when it turned out he had cancer."

 

Oh God... Dare he speak to Desmond about this? Darius sighs lightly and blinks slowly. What has he gotten himself into? What has he gotten /Joseph/ into? "It sounds like this Ian is a brave soul." He makes a point to not say 'was'. Hearing all this makes the lion hope even more that there is indeed something beyond the life they know. "May they both rest in peace. I know you made their last days as comfortable as they could be."

 

Isabelle sigghs and nods, "yes...their funeral is on tuesday, they shall be together forever now, me and Miss Singh have seen to that." She shakes her head, "I just wish I could do something about the Blood Meridian! But I am helpless to do anything,"

 

Now Darius feels absolutely terrible. Mentioning his affiliation with the group could put them both in grave danger. "I... I am sure the Wheel of Fate is due to turn." he says, hesitant through his shock. "Foul deeds rarely go unpunished." It is all he can think of to say in the way of comfort right now.

 

Isabelle nods her head, "Problem is....by that logic the same goes true for Mr Murdoch, fate turned and struck him down for being a hunter. It is the young man Ian...who did not deserve any of this."

 

"Sometimes people do extreme things for the ones they care about." Darius then says quietly. He has a certain loathing for hunters and slavers, but the lion would not go as far as to torture, just to prove a point. Has he made a mistake? All he can do at the moment is offer Isabelle the opportunity to talk about this. The poor woman seems to be quite heartbroken about the whole incident.

 

Isabelle sighs and sets her drink down as the food arrives, "I just need an escape for a few days." She looks at Darius and smiles, "I should impose myself upon your hospitality and come stay at yours for a few days. I made a promise to myself to get to know you better."

 

Although he smiles, Darius is beginning to believe that Isabelle is not going to think so fondly of him if she does get to know him better. He is, however, more than happy to spend time with a good friend. "That would not be imposing in the least bit, my friend." he tells her warmly. "I would love to have you over at any time."

 

Isabelle laughs, "Wonderful! Well as soon as I get the Karga family settled into their new home and all the furniture delivered I shall come and impose upon you."

 

Nodding, Darius grins a little. "You are always welcome in our home." he says, pleased to see her laugh. "As long as you don't mind stepping into the home of a lion." This is said jokingly, but not in a mocking manner. Many of his shifters had been afraid of being in his house at first, scared by the fact the master of the home was a big predator.

 

Isabelle laughs, "Darius compared to my father you are a big kitten." She smiles softly, "I shall bring F'wips along and a bag of shots and make sure to jab needles in the arms of all your staff. I still have not seen half of them."

 

"It will be nice to see F'wips again." The lion chuckles. Well, at least he does not have to worry about frightening her. Hopefully the young cat will not mind the smell of many shifters. "I will try to help convince them, but I do wish you luck in getting a needle close to some of my staff." he says before sighing. "They have problems trusting strangers, still." He knows it is for their health, but Darius cannot force any of his shifters to get an injection if they refuse it.

Isabelle nods her head, "I know, which is why...I think if I am there, staying with them and they get to know me, they will come to trust me more."

 

Darius nods back. "We can only hope. I see no reason why they would not take to you. You are my good friend, and a kind woman too." He smiles again. "You will love them, they are a pleasant group."

 

Isabelle sighs sadly, she wonders if he'd say that if he knew about her medical research facility and what she had down there. "It will be nice to get away.....and just unwind."

 

Watching the woman, Darius is curious about that little tint of sadness she shows. "Hopefully, you will be able to relax a little." he agrees with a warm tone. "It appears that you deserve it."

 

Isabelle smiles at darius, "As do you, perhaps we should go dancing you and I, I know a lovely place down Picadilly, ball room dancing into the night."

 

This thrills Darius, and he grins again. "That would be wonderful, Isabelle. I have not been dancing in so long." At least, not since he was in his late teens. "I would love to."

 

Isabelle smiles warmly, "I shall arrange it at once! There is nothing I used to enjoy more then going out of an evening and forgetting everything at the dance hall."

 

"Dancing used to be one of my favourite things in the world." Darius says, seemingly very happy with this arrangement. "It is a shame things often get in the way of what we enjoy." He watches Isabelle again, hoping that the issues with the Blood Meridian will not get in the way of these plans. "I am glad you have decided to take time off. You certainly deserve it."

 

Isabelle smiles, "I am sure my father shall be glad to hear I have taken time off. Now what say we take in a show at the theatre as well? I have front row seats any night I decide to show up at the Belfry."

 

The more she talks about him, the more curious Darius is about Isabelle's father. He seems like an interesting fellow. "That sounds lovely as well." He grins. "This promises to be a lot of fun. I look forward to it." Maybe he could use this as a time to distract himself from the issues at hand.

 

Isabelle stands up and smiles, "I shall return home and pack and see you this evening at your home, see you later Dear Darius." She leans over to kiss him on the cheek and then vanishes back out the door.

Darius and Isabelle meet again, and the lion gets some rather upsetting news about the Blood Meridian. Despite that, they make plans to spend some time together.
