It was dark as Simon Trebulet slipped from shadow to shadow to shadow down the street. His heart hammared in his cheast as he approched the fancy house with the black iron fence. Simon kept his head as he recalled the large layout of the home. His feet moved quickly aross the ground and silence hung in the night air as Simon pulled him self up and over the cool metal fence.

 

Even though it is late at night, the master of the home is wide awake. He sits up in his study, enjoying the silence of the night as he reads one of his books. Although comfortable in his chair, and in a focused trance while reading, Darius glances up and out the open window. A feeling, like a small instinct kicking him into paying attention, begins to bother him. He hears no sounds, and no strange smells float in through his window. The Frenchman closes his book and sets it on the table. For now, he will just sit and wait. The lion in him senses something, and he knows it is wise to listen. The light from the small lamp beside him would not be visable from outside, if anything or anyone should look that way.

 

Simon pauses on the other side of the black fence. He considers his options for a moment before he slowly removes his heavy boots. He sniff at on boot but the scent does not appear too strong. Simon sets the pair down by a fence post which has a broken tip, so that he would remember where they were hidden. Simon crouches down, low to the ground and his bird like eyes scan the property. There appears to be no security systems, cameras or gaurds. Simon gives himself a small nod of confidence and sets off at a run. The small thief darts across the fine lawn toward the house, his bare feet seem to only skim the groud and dew quickly coats his feet. Simon learns that the grass has been cut recently and his feet become flecked with small blades of grass. He cuts a diagonal path toward the left side of the house and the shadows that await him there.

 

Slowly, Darius gets to his feet and silently slinks towards the window. Something is bothering him, and the faintest of sounds only makes it worse. Something cutting through the air, the very softest of footfalls... the sharp-eared lion almost mistakes it for a breeze or a trick of his mind. However, his predatory skills and instincts do not lie. Moving to stand in the open doorway of his study, the aristocrat leans against the frame and waits again. Will this be a game of cat and mouse? Part of him hopes so.

 

Simon flattens his body to the wall. He was deep in the shadows yet he feels as though eyes are boreing into him. The theif's heart pounds once more. Sweat coats his foreheadbut Simon does little to rid himself of it. Simon takes a few deep breaths before he turns his attention to the tiny window above him. Simon generally finds that the flaw in most homes is these tiny windows. The windows provide a decent breeze but seem too small of a person to get through. The thief simply pops the screen off and pulls himself up onto the ledge. Simon slips through and lands softly on the inside. He crouches low and examines the room before him carefully.

 

The room Simon likely slipped into would be the front parlor, the main living room of the large house. The popping of the screen off the window definitely reaches the lion shifter's sharp ears, and his suspicions are proven to be true. Although usually a calm man, Darius lets his lips silently curl for a moment. His old home had been broken into, and that had ended in massive tragedy. /Never/ would he allow that to happen again. He has just as much to love and protect here than he did before that fateful night in France. Before long, the upstairs study is abandoned as Darius stalks out, shifted into his massive Barbary Lion form. His clothing is left in a heap on the floor by the chair. Slowly, with his skilful hunter's paws carrying him with minimal sound, the large cat makes his way to the top of the stairs and crouches. Waits. Amongst the scents of many shifters in the home, one faint one can just /barely/ be sensed, and it is not familiar.

 

Simon remains low on the ground. His eyes continue to dart around the room nervously. Simon remembers his father telling him long ago that some animals could sense danger. He supposed this could be true of crow shifters as well, for Simon was feeling as if hell itself could come crashing up from the floor. Simon took several more deep breaths. He tells himself that he is just scared as usual and that some old fogy probably lives here. Simon thinks of a friendly old man asleep in his armchair grasping an old book. The young man slowly stands and starts appraising artworks on the walls. He walks through the parlor room without creating a single sound. He is careful not to touch anything yet, because he has yet to determine whether or not security systems are in place on the objects themselves. Simon steps out of the room and looks left down a hallway towards the front door. He listens for a moment before turning right. His eyes meet the bottom of a staircase and his stomach is suddenly filled with a feeling of dread. He works his eyes slowly up the stairwell, one step at a time before his eyes meet that of a beast beyond Simon's imagination. The young thief's eyes widen in shock, as he looks into the creature's eyes say Sweet Mary mother of god... spoof before his world goes black as he faints and falls backward onto the floor.

 

Waiting is what a lion has to do when hunting. Wait for the right moment, wait for the one to stray and make itself vulnerable, wait for the prey to fall into a trap. His long tail swishing silently in anticipation, Darius finds his patience to be rewarding. The scent wafts up to him, the distinct smell of bird. And it is not the bird he knows. Golden eyes watch and wait, a shiver of joy crawling up his spine, the same as the criminal's line of sight crawls up the stairs. Why is he anticipating this so much? Once thier eyes meet, the lion's are filled with controlled anger and a predatory gleam. Just then, Darius springs up and bounds down the stairs before turning on a dime and circling around the fainted young man. He meets this with shock. Did the thief just... faint? A snarl escapes him, despite the light sting of concern. "Wake up." he demands in a human voice, his French accent thick through his anger. It is loud enough to hopefully stir the man back to consciousness, but hopefully not the rest of the house. He still circles, muscles tense and ready to pounce on Simon of this turns out to be a trick.

 

Simon's world is filled the sweet blackness that accompanies his blissful unconsciousness. A voice cuts through Simon's mind. "Beasts don't talk he mumbled. Suddenly the fear grippes Simon again. He sits bolt right up, with back to the great beast, Simon scrambles forward and turns staring up at the great beast. Simon begins to mumble the Lord's Prayer, "...give us this day our daily bread..." The young thief crosses himself repeatedly as he continues, "...Forgive my trespasses as I forgive those that tre... "

 

Darius is not a religious man, nor is he a very sympathetic one when it comes to an unwelcome stranger trespassing on his territory. He paces now in a semi-circle, slowly trying to herd the thief back towards the staircase. "Calm yourself." he says sharply, a beast's growl accompanying his voice. "You're right. Beasts don't talk, but this one does." If he can corner the thief at the stairs, he has him trapped. Unless the other shifter is brave enough to run past the angry lion or take a chance to vault the railing, that is. "What are you doing in my home?" he hisses over the young man's religious muttering. He knows the reason, but wants to see if the thief can talk for himself.

 

Simon's eyes widen further as the beast coerces him into a corner. Simon realizes that he was trapped and his heart begins to pound again. Simon swallows hard and speaks, "A-Aye... A ma-mans got to-to ea-ea... ea- /eat/... you know." As the words issued forth from his mouth Simon's fear was amplified. "Tha-that is to s-say that he-he doesn't need to-to eat /now/..." Simon pushed himself farther into the corner, shrinking as if he wished to disappear.

 

Feeling that he has frightened the young man enough, Darius uncurls his lips and relaxes a little. Luckily for Simon, this lion is not a killer, nor the stuffy breed of aristocrat that would have a young man thrown away in jail for the sake of pride and pettiness. He is, however, still angry. "A man can find himself a job. A man can find himself a soup kitchen." he replies, the growl now just a low rumble. The predatory instinct in him is loving this, while Darius actually wants to have empathy for him. Giving his great head a brief shake to clear his thoughts, Darius sits down. His tail curls around, the end flicking. "Leave my home. I do not want to see you here again, unless it is to tell me you have proper employment." While many may think this could be a joke, Darius is completely serious. When sitting, he offers Simon room to slip past him unharmed, unlock the front door, and escape.

Lorna takes the loaner instrument out of the case, and settles his in it.  She reaches up, and hangs the loaner on a hook.  "A violin as nice as that deserves a good job.  Most people don't care for copies, but I think all instruments deserve a loving hand.  I am glad you have it."

 

As he watches Lorna, Darius pauses for a moment. This case belongs to her, he never remembers purchasing it along with pay for the repair. "Miss," he begins, sounding the slightest bit confused as he lightly taps a finger on the edge of the violin case. "This belongs to you."

 

Lorna shakes her head and closes up the case.  "Now now...I didn't spend all that time working on that instrument to have it brought back to me in sorry condition within a week.  This is yours now."  She smiles kindly, then draws out a box from beneath her counter.  It's almost funny, to see the juxtaposition--a simple cardboard box, not hidden or guarded in any way (save Strad, who protects everything in the shop), and the box is filled with sheet music printed before the fall, some of it old enough to have been antique before the fall.  "And if you would like anything from here, I will give you a discount as well."  Even with a discount, the pieces are all worth thousands of creds.

 

Darius' warm smile returns. "Why, thank you very much. I promise I will not return for any repairs for a long time." His eyes settle on the box of sheet music, and a simple glance at it, at how near-ancient it is, and the lion's heart leaps with excitement. This is like his personal Holy Grail. "Where did you get these?" he asks, amazed.

 

Lorna blushes softly and looks away.  "They've...been mine since I was little."  She doesn't want to go into detail about her parents being aristocracy.

 

Eyes raising to look at Lorna again briefly, Darius offers an understanding nod. "Well, this looks like a wonderful collection. Are you sure you want to sell these?" Although he would buy every sheet if he could, the shifter is hesitant to purchase something that may be of more than credit value.

 

Lorna shakes her head.  "I'm certain.  Please, have a look."  She'd rather be rid of the reminders of her beginnings.  And, after having the shop trashed...she needed the money.

 

After being assured, Darius carefully looks through some of the sheets. Lorna might as well have shown a box of candy to a child. He is calm however, despite how excited he is to have an opportunity to look at and purchase something so special. "By the way, where did your piano go?" he asks while glancing through the music. "Little Strad here seems to be at a loss of what to chew on."

 

Strad's ears perk at that, and he looks up hopefully.  Lorna frowns, and looks over to where the piano once stood.  "It...got broken."  She'd done her best to clean up after everything, but little things here and there betray what had happened, glass dust on the floor, wood chips, she'd vacuumed repeatedly, but some bits had been ground into the carpet.

 

"Oh, I am very sorry to hear that. It was a fine instrument." Darius offers, although he finds it strange that a piano would ever simply 'get broken'. There has to be something more to that story. To him, it more looks like the paino was smashed to pieces, and the lion doubts that could happen by accident or because of a pup's chewing. However, he will not ask further on something that is not his business. After a moment, he finds two sheets that catches his eye, and sets them down carefully beside the box. He /really/ needs to stop spending credits like this. "I would like to purchase these two, please." he then states with another polite smile.

 

Lorna sets the box back down on the floor, and glances over the music.  "I thought you would like those.  For you, thirty thousand for the both of them."  She smiles warmly, having cut him an incredible deal.

 

Once again, the Frenchman brightens a little. "You are too kind, Miss." he tells Lorna warmly before reaching into his pocket for a credstick. Thankfully, he had brought a fair amount of credits with him, today. This is a wonderful change in his luck. He hands the credstick to the woman. "That should be enough."

 

Lorna slides it through the reader and hands it back.  "I hope they bring you much joy."  Meanwhile, Strad stands up and walks over to the box of music.  He regards it for a moment, and then sinks his teeth into the outstretched cardboard flap and begins to chew.

 

"Thank you very much." Darius replies with another nod. "I am sure they will." It is not every day he happens to find treasures like these. Then, his eyes move to look at the pup. "Um," is all he says, pointing a hand calmly towards the box being inflicted with a great assault. The dog is not his, so he can really do little to stop it.

 

Lorna yelps in surprise and bats at Strad.  "STRADIVARIUS!  Bad dog!!"  He seems to pout, and returns to his previous place, looking dejectedly at the chew toy.

 

With no harm done to the precious music, Darius can appreciate the humour in the pup's behavior. Again, he smiles while watching Strad. "There is a lot of personality in that dog." he comments. "I'm sure soon enough he will learn to accept his proper chew toy." There is a light chuckle in the shifter's voice as he speaks.

 

Lorna chuckles amusedly at everything.  "Yeah...he's a pest and a problem, but...he's the most loyal guard I ever could have hoped for.  Though I'm not sure loyal to what...when that...reptile shifter broke the piano, I don't know if Strad was protecting me, or avenging his piano."

 

He had guessed that there was more to the piano incident. Darius looks at Lorna again, one eyebrow raised a tiny bit. He knows not to inquire further. "I am sorry to hear that happened. But aside from his chewing dilemma, Stradivarius seems very happy here with you. I have no doubt that he was protecting you during the incident. From what I've seen, dogs show loyalty from a very early age."

 

Lorna smiles warmly and leans down to pet the pup.  "Yeah...he's so smart...I almost wonder if he's going to shift to a human form one of these days."  She laughs and shakes her head.  "But he's all dog...and I love him."  Strad as well, seems pleased, and he nuzzles against Lorna's fingers.

 

Seeing this makes Darius begin to miss his father's dogs back home. Although the cat in him might say otherwise, he thinks canines are beautiful creatures. "You treat him well, and he seems to love you too." he says with a small smile. In all that happened with the music and the pup, the lion had forgotten about the other things he must do before the day is over. "I should probably get going, I have some more errands to run after I take these things home. Thank you so much for everything, Miss."

 

Lorna nods and slinks back into the back room.  "Of course.  Come back any time."  Strad stays out in the front, and he walks over to Darius before he leaves.  He leans up, and licks the man's hand, then returns to chewing the edge of the cardboard box the music is in.
Darius returns to the music shop to pick up his violin.

Lady Isabelle is sat in a chair, staring at her PADD in a listless manner, her guards are hovering nearby, waiting to take the dejected lady home.

 

Having taken up a habit of walking through the garden almost every day, Darius strolls along the pathway at a slow, relaxed pace. Although he has been here almost every day since he had discovered it, the shifter still seems fascinated by the flowers and caged birds. As he walks by and observes a cluster of red geraniums, seemingly highlighted by the sunset, a scent other than the natural perfume of flowers catches his attention. Isabelle looks up over her PADD and sighs, sliding the stylus home and rising, she looks tired and worn out. "Hello Lord Darius, good day to you."

Isabelle smiles and sits back down now that the niceities are over with, "As well as can be expected Darius dear." She smiles at him, "I have...some cancer patients in my care right now, looking after them is proving to be difficult."

Isabelle smiles and leans back, "Yes, that they are my friend, that they are, though there is little I can do for one of them, he will be dead within the month." She shakes her head, "Though soon, soon he will rest peacefully."

 

That kind of news is always heartbreaking, even if you do not know the poor soul. Darius can only guess how hard it might be for the Lady, or her patient's loved ones. Isabelle smiles and leans over, plucking tulip and smelling it with a sigh, "I...came here to relax, I am glad you came along, you made me put away my work when otherwise I would have continued writing."

Isabelle holds the tulip in her fingers and then inclines her head, "Yes my lord, my friend, most important indeed/" Isabelle says, "Would you care to walk with me amongst the flowers"

 

As his eyes return to Isabelle, Darius' smile widens a little. "I would enjoy that very much." as he speaks, the Frenchman extends a hand to help the lady up. Forever the gentleman.

 

Isabelle accepts the hand and walks alongside him amongst all blossoms, "This is one of my favourite places to stroll."

Isabelle chuckles, "Indeed it was, that was a most pleasent day, I simply must have you down to the Na'Ostiria estate soon, I shall take you on a tour of our own gardens. Show  you what we have created on the outskirts of the city."

 

"On the outskirts of the city?" Darius repeats, looking at Isabelle curiously. "That sounds like quite the achievement." The man chuckles lightly. "I can hardly keep a garden in my own yard."

 

Isabelle smiles warmly at him and pats his arm, "We have...our own cistern and water source, so we have been able to irrigate quite a large aread."

 

Nodding, the lion shifter smiles back. "Quite impressive. I would love to see this garden of yours sometime." he says warmly. "I don't believe I have ventured as far as the city outskirts, either. I hear it is mainly sand, but I am still curious to have a look."

 

Isabelle smiles, "Some of us, have estates out there, little plots of land we have walled off and made out own over time, it is....quite a lovely place to see really. Even the desert is filled with life if you look at it the right way."

 

Again, Darius thinks for a moment. "I believe I heard something along those lines, of larger properties even nicer than on the upper level. I did not think much of it, and just settled myself up here." He glances around at the garden surrounding them again. "Perhaps I never thought that the desert could hold this kind of beauty." the lion adds, gesturing to the flowers.

 

Isabelle smiles, "You would be surprised, what the desert looks like after the rain, only for a few hours but it blooms, it blooms like there is no tomorrow."

 

As much as he has read about things like this in books, the shifter never really thought it was possible. His eyebrows raise a little. "Really? I would love to see that. It would definitely prove me wrong, wouldn't it?"

 

Isabelle smiles, "It would my friend." She stands on tip-toes and kisses his cheek, "Come out soon, maybe tomorrow and I will show it to you my friend."

 

The kiss on the cheek is a little unexpected, but Darius does not show it. He just keeps his smile. "I will." he replies with a nod. "Thank you very much, Lady Na'Ostiria."

 

Isabelle she nods her head and smiles, "It will be nice, to have a distraction after work in the evening now. Until then Darius."

 

"Have yourself a wonderful evening." he says before glancing towards the darkening sky quickly. Ever since his little incident last week, well, even the lion is a little uneasy being outside in the dark. Even up here in the safety of the upper level. "Try not to work too hard." the man offers before bowing his head a little and walking back the way he came.

 

Isabelle inclines her head and turns for the exit, her guards falling in beside her as she leaves.
Isabelle and Darius meet in the garden again, and have a nice chat. The Lady invites him to visit her estate.

The monorail moves along, making the appropriate stops on it's way towards the lower level as Darius En sits at one end of the car, reading a newspaper left on a vacant seat. At rainway Station Skia staggers onto the carriage, clutching a brown paper parcel in one arm and pressing his hand to his neck. A handkerchief wrapped about his throat. He sinks into a chair panting and looking somewhat ill.

 

As with every other stop, Darius is unmoving, and does not stop reading his paper. However, an interesting sight in the corner of his vision, and a familiar scent makes the shifter raise his head, and his eyes set on Skia before widening a tiny bit. "Skia." Skia peers at the lion and shifts his package, the lion can probably smell blood on the iar. "Vampire." he mutters angrily.

Skia sqeuaks and leans against the lion, the kid looks like he is on the verge of tears. Skia hangs his head and sighs, "I...am going to keep doing it. But only once or twice a week, and not every week..." he sighs and shakes his head, "I think i'm in more...danger...from the BM then I am from that job."

 

The lion shifter gains a serious expression. "I will not let the Blood Meridian harm you." he says, tone implying nothing can be said to convince him otherwise. Skia nods his head and reaches down to squeeze the lions hand, "You...are a good man Darius...I am glad you are here in Bleaker."

Skia nods his head and looks at the bird, "Nice to meet you too Sir Gabriel." The bird flaps his wings and shrieks. Skia turns to look at the door. "I ...should go inside.."

 

"Alright. Please take care of yourself." Darius says, still smiling. "And rest for the next few days." As he speaks, the lion shifter lowers his hand before reaching one up again to stroke Gabriel's back gently.

 

The eagle flaps its wings and leans down to peer intently at its prey, the squirrel. The squirrel nods and opens the door to the doctors house. "Yea...ok see you soon."

His eyes wandering and soaking in the somewhat gloomy scenery, Darius walks at a slow, but steady pace. Once again the lion shifter is exploring, but this time he has an actual destination in mind. The Belfry, the place mentioned by a certain puma shifter a couple days ago, has been a subject of interest and curiosity for him. As he nears the old building, Darius slows down even more and looks at it with a calculating eye. He has little reason beyond curiosity to explore further. As he pauses to think, a slight waft of a familiar scent disturbs his focus. The shifter turns around, and it is not long until his eyes settle on the other male feline from a couple days ago. Well, how convenient. "Mister Cusick." He says with a light, friendly tone. He smiles, secretly allowing this chance meeting to make his day. "Good afternoon."

 

When his name is spoken, Desmond gives a start, musings interrupted by the vaguely familiar voice.  He was so enthralled with the goings-on in his mind that he seems almost surprised to find himself in the yard, and he pauses in step, glancing at Darius with lifted eyebrows.  The shock is quickly overcome, however, and the puma offers a faint smile, inclining his head in greeting.  "And the same to you, Mister En," he intones, the lion's genial tone echoed in his own.  "I see you took my advice."

 

Darius glances back to look at the building of the Belfry, smiling again. "Yes, I wanted to see if the Belfry was as wonderful as you suggested." He replies. He is anxious to ask questions, but the lion takes his time. There is no reason to figuratively pounce on the puma with his inquiries. "How are you today?" He can be polite as much as he needs, he does not want to risk making his burning curiosity seem suspicious.

 

The puma's gaze also goes to the Belfry, admiring its archaic architecture and the ominous pall it casts over the area.  It truly is one of the marvels in Bleaker.  Desmond owes a lot to this building and those within it.  "Tired," he responds, slowing stepping forward, "but these days, I would be hard-pressed to find someone who isn't."  He smirks slightly, coming to a halt not far from Darius.  "What do you think of it?" he adds, eyes still locked on the old church.

 

For a short moment, instinct tells Darius to watch the puma carefully as he approaches. Perhaps it is the mystery surrounding the other shifter, but he feels like he needs to be cautious. The lion follows his gaze to look back at the Belfry, nodding once. "A beautiful building. I have yet to see inside, but the exterior is quite impressive." Darius replies, sincerely quite amazed by the church. Not many buildings in Bleaker are as pleasing to the eye.

 

"It is," Desmond agrees, bobbing his head a little and pushing his hands deeper into his pockets.  The smirk broadens further and he glances finally to Darius.  "Really, though, it's what is inside that impresses most of all."  Or, more importantly, /who/ is inside.  Now that he and the lion are alone, he doesn't feel the need to speak cryptically.  "You may find many in there who share your . . . particular inclinations towards our kind."

 

"Is that so?" Darius asks, tone giving away his peaked interest. "Then perhaps I made a good decision to come down this way." He smiles at Desmond, while trying to read his expression. There is something else about him, the lion can tell. However, that once of mystery is impossible to figure out. "I can assume you come here often? You seem to know this place well."

 

The smirk breaks into an amused grin, and Desmond breathes out a soft chuckle, dipping his face briefly to glance at the street beneath him.  Darius has apparently made a joke, though it's unlikely the lion will realize it.  "No, I don't come here often," the puma responds, lifting his head again.  "I used to, but I rarely find the time anymore."  He jerks his chin toward the Belfry, indicating it.  "You ought to speak with Mara Phoenix, should you venture in.  Tell her I sent you.  You and she share methods and interests in the freeing of slaves."

 

Darius turns his head to look at Desmond again, not really seeing what the puma finds so amusing. He lets it slide, however, and listens to the other man's words. Mara Phoenix. He will definitely remember that. He lifts one eyebrow a tiny bit. "Really? It has been a bit of a struggle to find another with interest in freeing slaves." The lion begins to venture a little and test the waters, so to speak. "Especially with peaceful methods. I am not against more bold movements, but it might be nice to meet someone else who shares a similar vision."

 

Once again, Desmond grins, but it's not so much at an internal joke than it is at Darius' words themselves.  "You will find few more peaceful than those who work in the Belfry," he utters.  "Too peaceful for my tastes, but others like yourself may find it to your liking."  The puma likes to make statements--big, loud, explosive statements that can't be ignored.

 

"Oh?" the curiosity within the lion is only made less bearable by Desmond's words. Too peaceful for his tastes? With a faint sigh, Darius looks at the old church for a moment, definitely wanting to venture inside and have a look around sometime in the near future. "I suppose everyone has different methods. Maybe soon I will be able to make myself heard in a more... effective way." He says whilst deep in thought. "As much as I sometimes think I have helped, a small handful of shifters in my care and lots of credits thrown about is not all that big of an accomplishment. Peaceful is pricey, and unfortunately not that big of an influence."

 

"I could not agree more, though less peaceful methods are not altogether cheap either."  Desmond knows this well, and his tone would indicate such.  "Fortunately, such tactics are much more effective than those of a less violent nature.  If it is these that interest you, there are other people who specialize in such things."  And by the sound of it, he knows exactly who they are.  Why shouldn't he?  He /is/ one of those people.

 

This is just sparking a million questions at once within Darius' mind, but he remains calm and collected. "Perhaps I might be interested. And if these less peaceful tactics are for the same reason I am trying to buy the freedom of slaves, I would be happy to get involved. However, not if the safety of those in my household are at any risk. No statement is worth putting them in danger. I work hard to make sure they are safe, and I will not allow that security to be dashed away from them." His tone is assertive, and sounding as if he is quite serious about the matter. He eyes Desmond, knowing he is talking to the right person about this subject.

 

Yes, he certainly is.  Desmond smirks again.  "Naturally," he intones, nodding his head slowly.  "I can assure you that, though they are known for making a bang, these people are masters of discretion.  Perhaps you have heard of the Blood Meridian?"  Darius may be new in town, but it wouldn't surprise the puma in the least.

 

Darius' eyes show a bit of his amused surprise. It is not that the Blood Meridian would have an involvement in these things, but that Desmond has already answered so many questions with a simple sentence. "I have heard of them, yes." He replies with a slow nod, still watching the other feline intently. The things he has heard have not been very positive, but they came from a squirrel shifter who had obviously had a sore past with these people. "Not much, however. My attempts to gain more information to ease my curiosity have not been very successful. Other than rumours, information about this 'Blood Meridian' seems well protected."

 

That brings another grin to Desmond's lips.  "As I said," he chuckles, "they are masters of discretion."  Naturally, information about the group would be hard to come by, if one did not know where to look, who to ask.  "What is it you wish to know?"

 

"I want to know what the purpose is of the group." Darius replies, deciding not to tiptoe around this any longer. He has an opportunity to get information, and would be a fool to miss it. "I know there are shifter groups out there, and although I want nothing to do with the politics between them, I am curious to know what they are about. Also, I would like to find out how active they are in the struggle against slavers and hunters. I am guessing they play a big part in it, but I am curious as to how far they carry their tactics." Darius may be willing to play a part in these efforts to stop the cruelty against shifters, but he needs to know what he may be getting himself into if he does.

 

However, Desmond has not gotten this far by being overly forthcoming with information.  His response is worded carefully, attempting to answer the questions posed to him without giving away anything vital: "The purpose of the Meridian is to see that those who oppress our kind are brought down.  Slavers and hunters both--hunters especially.  Their tactics may be considered barbaric and violent to some, but they are careful at least not to harm other shifters, if such is possible."  And it usually is.

 

Raising and lowering his head in a slow nod, Darius seems to think for a moment. "Interesting." He replies simply, absent-mindedly tapping the end of his folded umbrella on the pavement beside his feet a couple times as he considers this information. "I can understand why they would be so careful, if dealing with dangerous people." However, the mention of care to prevent any harm to other shifters does help ease his mind a little. As much as he wants to keep out of violent practises to protect his shifters, the want to make a difference is strong within the lion. And it is not below him to get his hands dirty once in a while. "Would this group be interested in accepting help? In any way?" He may not be so willing to spill credits into something he knows little about, but helping finance these acts of protest is one of the best ways he can help.

 

"Perhaps."  Funding a terrorist group is such a trial, and financial backing is always welcome.  As it is right now, the Meridian is easily affordable to Desmond, and he likes to keep it within that bracket to avoid dependency on outside sources--sources that could fall through at later dates.  He is, however, not against having said resources available upon request.  The smirk returns as he inclines his head slightly.  "We would be fools to turn down any help offered, and I'm sure you would be a wonderful asset to the cause.  If we have need of you, I will not be certain to let you know."  It's the first solid indication he's given of his involvement in the Meridian itself.

 

This time it is Darius' turn to smirk, as his inclinations are put to a rest. That nagging suspicion finally eases, and the lion feels a sense of closure. Getting himself involved had proved easier than suspected, but he wants to make sure that he is not just a backup plan. If he is going to be of any help, he needs to be aware of what the Blood Meridian is doing. That should come in baby steps, however. "If there is /anything/ you or the group needs, don't hesitate to come find me, Mister Cusick. I intend on being as much of an asset as you suggest." He has a healthy sum of funds, shelter in his home, and a lion within him that yearns for something new. Something dangerous. To him, he is not offering a helping hand to terrorists. Many races have needed to carve thier own safe place in the world through these means, way before shifters existed. This just feels like the right thing to do. 'Peaceful' just may become a thing of Darius' past.

 

"Please," Desmond chuckles, smile growing, "call me 'Desmond'.  I reserve 'Mister Cusick' for those who have a reason to fear me."  And if Darius is going to be an ally, he has no need of formalities.  "I believe you, and perhaps a member of your household, may be of a great deal of use in the future, but I suppose that can be saved for a later discussion.  I really should be getting along now."  He extends a hand courteously, the smile breaking into a grin.

 

"Alright then, Desmond." The lion shifter says with a polite, accomplished smile as he firmly shakes the other man's hand. "Thank you very much for your time." This is said with great sincerity, as he would never have found out or gained so much if the puma had not stopped to talk with him. "Have yourself a good day."

Perhaps I was quick to judge the Upper Level folks.

I have always percieved them as 'stuffy', as I never got a chance to meet my neighbors or talk to anyone up here. We all live in luxury while the less fortunate are starving, or bought and sold like property. I have tried doing my part to help, but I know I should be doing more.

I encountered Lady Na'Ostiria in the beautiful garden this morning, and a simple greeting turned into an invitation to have some tea. She is a lovely woman, quite intellegant as well. Her pet seems to be a jaguar kitten, I hope she is aware of how big it shall get. The little cat did not take to me, sometimes I forget my scent could make some animals nervous.

Her cousin came along after a while too. He is a nice young man. It is a shame that the Lady had to go. Some sort of emergency, I suppose. I must invite her to lunch to thank her for the tea.

Another man, one that apparently the Lady knows, joined us. He goes by the name of Desmond Cusick. I must say, something about him had me thinking. It is not just the fact he is a feline shifter as well, but there is something about the man that still bothers me. He knows a lot more than he let on. He was curious about my efforts to free shifters from slavery, though he did not seem impressed with my methods. I do what I can. I could make a violent stand, but what would that say about shifters? How would that make us all look? What would my family of freed slaves do if I was to fall victim to a retaliation?

Desmond may have some answers that I have been seeking. Maybe he knows something about the feline group Skia warned me about. He seemed enthusiatic about freeing shifter slaves, and looked pleased when mentioning more violent acts against the guild. Maybe he knows something. That puma is more than a merchant. And I intend to run into him again. I need answers.
